title: Getting Started with Machine Learning: A Mathematician's Perspective
headline: How I discovered that machine learning is just fancy math with computers
searchDescription: A beginner-friendly guide to machine learning from someone who thought they knew math until they met neural networks
excerpt: When I first started learning machine learning, I thought my mathematical background would make it easy. Boy, was I wrong...

content.text: When I first started learning machine learning, I thought my mathematical background would make it easy. Boy, was I wrong. Machine learning is like math's rebellious teenager - it uses all the same principles but insists on doing things its own way.
In this post, I'll share my journey from mathematical theory to practical ML applications, including the mistakes I made and the lessons I learned along the way.
The Mathematical Foundation

At its core, machine learning is built on three mathematical pillars: linear algebra, calculus, and statistics. But here's the thing - understanding these concepts theoretically is one thing. Applying them to real-world problems is a completely different beast.

content.caption: How linear algebra, calculus, and statistics come together in ML

content.text: My First Neural Network
I decided to start with a simple neural network for image classification. Here's the code that changed everything for me:

content.code:
import tensorflow as tf
from tensorflow import keras

# Define a simple neural network
model = keras.Sequential([
    keras.layers.Flatten(input_shape=(28, 28)),
    keras.layers.Dense(128, activation='relu'),
    keras.layers.Dropout(0.2),
    keras.layers.Dense(10, activation='softmax')
])

# Compile the model
model.compile(optimizer='adam',
              loss='sparse_categorical_crossentropy',
              metrics=['accuracy'])

content.text: This simple 10-line code block took me three days to understand. The math behind it? That took another week. But once I got it, everything clicked.
The Learning Curve
Here's what I wish someone had told me when I started:

items: Start with simple problems - don't try to build GPT-4 on day one
Focus on understanding the intuition, not just the math
Practice with real datasets, not just toy examples
Join communities and don't be afraid to ask questions

content.caption: The infamous learning curve - it gets better, I promise!

content.text: Key Takeaways
After months of learning and building, here are my main takeaways:
1. **Mathematics is your friend**: Your mathematical background will help you understand the underlying principles, even if the implementation seems foreign at first.
2. **Practice beats theory**: You can read all the papers in the world, but nothing beats building and experimenting with real models.
3. **Start simple**: Begin with linear regression and work your way up. Don't skip the fundamentals.
4. **Community matters**: The ML community is incredibly supportive. Don't hesitate to ask questions and share your journey.
What's Next?
I'm currently working on more advanced topics like computer vision and natural language processing. The journey never really ends - there's always something new to learn.
If you're just starting your ML journey, remember: every expert was once a beginner. Take it one step at a time, and don't be afraid to make mistakes. That's how we learn.

title: Building My First SaaS Product: Lessons from the Trenches
headline: How I went from 'I can code' to 'I can build a business' (and almost lost my mind)
searchDescription: The real story behind building a SaaS product - the good, the bad, and the 'why did I think this was a good idea' moments
excerpt: Building a SaaS product is like having a baby - it's exciting, terrifying, and you have no idea what you're doing...

content.text: Building a SaaS product is like having a baby - it's exciting, terrifying, and you have no idea what you're doing. But unlike having a baby, you can't return it to the hospital if things go wrong.
In this post, I'll share the honest truth about building my first SaaS product, including the mistakes I made, the lessons I learned, and why I'm still doing it despite everything.
The Idea Phase
It all started with a simple problem: I was tired of manually managing my projects and wanted something that could help me stay organized. Simple, right? Wrong.

The Business Side
Here's what I learned about the business side of SaaS:

items: Customer support is a full-time job
Legal compliance is boring but necessary

content.caption: My first dashboard - it was mostly red numbers

content.text: The Emotional Rollercoaster

Building a SaaS product is an emotional rollercoaster. One day you're on top of the world because someone actually paid for your product. The next day you're questioning everything because your server crashed and you lost all your users.
The key is to focus on the long-term vision and not get too caught up in the daily ups and downs. Easier said than done, I know.
What I'd Do Differently
If I could go back and do it all over again, here's what I'd change:

items: Start with a smaller, more focused MVP
Get user feedback earlier and more often
Invest in proper testing from the beginning
Focus on one market segment initially

content.text: The Bottom Line
Building a SaaS product is hard. Really hard. But it's also incredibly rewarding. The feeling of seeing someone use your product and get value from it is indescribable.

If you're thinking about building a SaaS product, my advice is simple: start small, focus on solving a real problem, and don't give up when things get tough. Because they will get tough. But it's worth it.
